In the context of the social and political unrest that characterised the early 1990s in Romania, the events of 29 January 1990 in University Square in Bucharest, as described in the decision issued by the prosecutor’s office at the High Court of Cassation and Justice on 17 June 2009, are particularly significant. They demonstrate the tensions that existed between the former communist authorities and the new political forces that emerged in the aftermath of the fall of the Ceauşescu regime, as well as the violent clashes that could occur between different groups of demonstrators.
26.  The events of 29 January 1990 in University Square in Bucharest also highlight the role played by the security forces in managing and controlling public demonstrations, as well as the potential for violence and unrest that could arise in such situations.
27.  In light of the foregoing, it is important to ensure that the events of 29 January 1990 in University Square in Bucharest are thoroughly investigated, and that those responsible for any human rights violations that may have occurred are held accountable. This is essential for ensuring that the rule of law is upheld, and for promoting a culture of respect for human rights and the principles of democracy in Romania.
28.  The European Court of Human Rights has also played a significant role in promoting respect for human rights in Romania, and in ensuring that those who have been victims of human rights violations have access to justice. In a number of landmark cases, the Court has found that Romania has violated various provisions of the European Convention on Human Rights, including the right to life, the prohibition of torture and inhuman or degrading treatment, and the right to a fair trial.

Subject: Request for Investigation of Torture and Inhumane Treatment

Dear Sir/Madam,

I am writing to request an investigation into the torture and inhumane treatment I was subjected to during my detention in 2010. I was arrested on suspicion of robbery and taken into custody at the Kyiv Department of the Ministry of Internal Affairs. During my detention, I was beaten, electrocuted, and threatened with torture until I confessed to a crime I did not commit.

I was taken to a pre-trial detention center, where I was held in a cell with no windows and only a hole in the ground as a toilet. The conditions were inhumane, and I was not provided with adequate food, water, or medical care. I was forced to sleep on the floor without a mattress or blanket, and I was not allowed to wear any warm clothing.

I was interrogated for hours on end, and when I refused to confess, I was beaten with a truncheon and electrocuted with a taser. I was also threatened with further torture and told that my family would be harmed if I did not confess.

I was eventually charged with robbery and sentenced to 12 years in prison. I was released in 2018 after serving eight years of my sentence.

I am writing to request an investigation into the actions of the officers who were responsible for my torture and inhumane treatment. I believe that my rights were violated, and I want to ensure that those responsible are held accountable for their actions.

I

´Western´ influence. The government has not yet taken any measures to protect the girls from FGM. The government is not willing to take any measures because it considers FGM a religious and cultural tradition.
The Sudanese government is not willing to take any measures to protect girls from FGM because it considers it a religious and cultural tradition.
In the Sudanese Penal Code, female genital mutilation (FGM) is not specifically mentioned as a criminal offence. The Criminal Code only refers to FGM in general terms, without any further definition, leaving the interpretation of the legislative provision to the judge. In practice, those who commit FGM are not prosecuted.
FGM is still being carried out at a large scale in Sudan. Girls are circumcised traditionally to prepare them for marriage, for religious reasons and – based on superstition – for ‘health reasons’. The most recent estimate of the percentage of circumcised women between 15-49 years old in Sudan is 89%.
UNICEF and UNFPA conduct large-scale campaigns to stop FGM. These campaigns have rendered circumcision a topic of debate. Discussions are being held within families and in the press and on social media, even photographs are being shown. However, there is also a strong influence of the pro-FGM lobby which presents it as traditional values and norms being affected by the ‘Western’ influence. The government has not yet taken any measures to protect the girls from FGM. The government is not willing to take any measures because it considers FGM a religious and cultural tradition.

The decision included the following measures: (1) construction of a flood protection embankment along the Kholzunovka River; (2) construction of a drainage system in the floodplain; (3) land reclamation and afforestation in the floodplain; and (4) evacuation of residents from the most dangerous areas. The rain caused significant damage to the area. In particular, the rain caused a landslide in the area of the 26th of August, which resulted in the death of two people and the destruction of a number of buildings. The landslide was caused by the intense rainfall that fell in a short period of time, which resulted in the saturation of the soil and the collapse of the slope.

The plaintiff, who was a resident of the area, brought an action against the State for damages resulting from the landslide. The plaintiff alleged that the State was liable for the damage caused by the landslide as a result of the inadequate maintenance of the slope.

The State argued that it was not liable for the damage caused by the landslide as it was an unforeseeable event and that the damage was caused by an exceptional meteorological event, which was beyond the control of the State.

The Court found that the State was liable for the damage caused by the landslide. The Court held that the State had failed to take adequate measures to maintain the slope and that the landslide was a direct consequence of the State’s failure to fulfil its obligations. The Court also held that the exceptional meteorological event was not the sole cause of the damage, as the intensity of the rain was not unforeseeable and that the State could have taken measures to prevent the damage caused by the landslide.

The Court ordered the State to pay damages to the plaintiff for the damage caused by the landslide. The amount of damages was determined by the Court based on the evidence presented during the trial.

Overall, this case demonstrates the importance of the State’s obligation to take adequate measures to maintain public areas and prevent damage caused by natural disasters. The State cannot rely on exceptional circumstances to avoid its responsibilities towards its citizens.

The Court reiterates that, in the context of Article 5 of the Convention, a “deprivation of liberty” may occur not only where a person is detained but also where his freedom to leave is restricted by the presence of officials or other circumstances amounting to a de facto deprivation of liberty. In the present case, the Court notes that the second applicant was not detained but was prevented from leaving his house by the abductors. Therefore, the Court finds that there has been a deprivation of liberty within the meaning of Article 5 of the Convention.

The Court further notes that the second applicant has not been provided with any information about the whereabouts of Beslan Baysultanov or the reasons for his detention. This constitutes

2010 its priority. The government continued to use the fight against terrorism as a pretext to restrict human rights and civil liberties, including through the adoption of a new Criminal Code provision that criminalized ‘incitement of ethnic or religious hatred’.
The authorities continued to restrict freedom of expression and association, particularly in the context of political opposition and civil society activism. Journalists and human rights defenders faced harassment, intimidation and imprisonment on spurious charges. The authorities also restricted freedom of assembly, often using excessive force to disperse peaceful demonstrations.
The authorities continued to restrict the rights of ethnic and religious minorities, particularly in the context of the implementation of the government’s policy of ‘Kazakhstanisation’, which aimed to promote Kazakh language and culture and to restrict the use of minority languages.

Domestic violence remained a widespread problem, but the authorities failed to address it effectively. the Kok-Kaynar River, in the  Aksai region of the Kyrgyz Republic.  The mudslide was caused by the collapse of a rock slope, which resulted in the death of 20 people and the destruction of 13 houses.

In connection with the above, we would like to inform you that our Institute has conducted a comprehensive study of the causes of the mudslide, and has prepared a set of recommendations for preventing similar disasters in the future.

We believe that the measures recommended in our report will significantly reduce the risk of mudslides and other geological disasters in the region, and we would be grateful if you could consider them in your planning and decision-making processes.

We would be happy to provide you with a copy of our report, and to discuss the recommendations with you in more detail, if you so wish.”

1.  The recommendations made by the Mountain Institute in its report on the causes of the mudslide in the Kok-Kaynar River valley, and in its letter to the President of the KBR, were as follows:
*  To conduct a comprehensive geological survey of the area, with a view to identifying and mapping potential landslide and other geological hazards.
*  To establish a system of regular monitoring and early warning of geological hazards, using a combination of remote sensing and ground-based techniques.
*  To develop and implement a system of land-use planning and zoning, which takes into account the geological hazards and other environmental factors in the area.
*  To establish a system of emergency response and disaster preparedness, which can be activated in the event of a geological disaster.
*  To provide training and education for local communities and government agencies, to increase awareness of the risks and to develop the necessary skills and knowledge for preventing and responding to geological disasters.
*  To promote sustainable land use practices, such as soil conservation and reforestation, which can help to reduce the risk of geological disasters.
*  To establish partnerships and cooperation with other organisations and agencies, both within the Kyrgyz Republic and internationally, to share knowledge and experience, and to access funding and other resources for geological hazard prevention and management

The European Union has also recognised the need to protect the rights of Gypsies. In 2003, the EU adopted a Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies up to 2020. The aim of this framework is to improve the situation of Roma, including Gypsies, in areas such as education, employment, housing and health.
Despite these efforts, the situation of Gypsies remains a matter of concern. Many Gypsies still face discrimination and marginalisation. They are often excluded from mainstream society and are denied access to basic rights and services.
The Council of Europe and the European Union must continue to work together to promote the rights of Gypsies and to combat discrimination and marginalisation. On 12 July 1989, the Sofia Regional Court ruled that the removal of the Batalova Vodenitsa residents was illegal and ordered their return to their homes.  The court decision was based on the fact that the residents had been removed from their homes without a court order and that their removal had been carried out in violation of the law on urban planning and construction.  The court also ruled that the residents were entitled to compensation for the damage they had suffered as a result of their removal.

The court decision was widely publicized in the media and was seen as a major victory for the residents and their supporters.  It was also seen as a sign that the authorities were beginning to take seriously the issue of illegal removal of people from their homes.  However, the authorities did not immediately comply with the court decision and the residents were not returned to their homes.

In the months that followed, there were numerous protests and demonstrations in support of the Batalova Vodenitsa residents.  The authorities responded with force, using police and military units to break up the protests and arrest the protesters.  The authorities also used various tactics to intimidate and harass the residents and their supporters, including surveillance, threats, and harassment.

In September 1989, the authorities announced that they would comply with the court decision and allow the Batalova Vodenitsa residents to return to their homes.  However, the authorities imposed a number of conditions on the residents, including the requirement that they pay for the damage caused to their homes during the removal process.  The residents refused to pay the damages and continued to demand a full restoration of their rights.

The Batalova Vodenitsa case was widely covered in the media and was seen as a symbol of the struggle for human rights and democracy in Bulgaria.  The case also contributed to the growing movement for political change in the country, which ultimately led to the fall of the communist regime in November 1989.

Europe date back to the 16th century. Since then, the Roma have been subjected to various forms of discrimination and persecution, including forced assimilation, expulsions, and genocide.

The Roma are a diverse and heterogeneous people, with their own distinctive cultural, linguistic, and religious traditions. They are divided into several subgroups, including Sinti, Kale, and others, and are found in various countries throughout Europe, including Spain, France, Germany, Italy, and the United Kingdom.

The Roma are often associated with poverty, social exclusion, and marginalization, which are the result of historical and structural factors such as discrimination, racism, and social prejudice. Despite their rich cultural heritage and contributions to European society, the Roma continue to face significant challenges in accessing education, employment, healthcare, and other basic rights and services.

The situation of the Roma in Europe has been the subject of international concern and attention for many years, and various initiatives and policies have been developed to address their needs and promote their integration into mainstream society. However, much remains to be done to ensure that the Roma enjoy full and equal citizenship rights and opportunities, and to combat the persistent and pervasive forms of discrimination and prejudice that they continue to face.

The first applicant submitted that her son had been abducted by State agents and that his fate remained unknown. She relied on Article 2 of the Convention, which provides that everyone's right to life shall be protected by law. She submitted that the authorities had failed to conduct an effective investigation into her son's disappearance, and that the State had not taken any measures to prevent similar violations in the future.

The Government submitted that the applicant's complaint was inadmissible as it had not been substantiated by any evidence. They also noted that the investigation had been conducted and that the applicant had been informed of the progress of the investigation.

The Court found that the applicant's complaint under Article 2 of the Convention was admissible. It noted that the applicant's son had been last seen in the company of servicemen in camouflage uniforms and that his fate remained unknown. The Court also noted that the investigation had not been effective and that the authorities had not taken any measures to prevent similar violations in the future.

Under Article 2 of the Convention, the State has a positive obligation to protect the right to life. In the present case, the Court found that the State had failed to fulfil this obligation as it had not conducted an effective investigation into the applicant's son's disappearance. The Court also noted that the applicant had been denied access to effective remedies, as she had not been able to obtain any information about the investigation or the fate of her son.

The Court found a violation of Article 2 of the Convention and ordered the respondent State to pay the applicant 50,000 euros in respect of non-pecuniary damage.

It is clear from the evidence before the Court that the medical facilities in the applicant's prison are inadequate and that there is a serious shortage of medical personnel. It is also clear that the applicant has been denied access to adequate medical care for a prolonged period of time.

Finally, I would like to emphasize that the Court's jurisdiction under Article 5 of the Convention is not limited to the review of individual detentions, but also extends to the review of the conditions of detention. In the present case, the applicant's detention conditions, including the inadequate medical care, amount to a breach of Article 3 of the Convention. I would therefore also make a declaration to that effect.

The fact that the applicant was handcuffed each time he was separated from the isolated group, even when he was in the exercise yard, appears to be an unnecessary and disproportionate restriction of his freedom of movement. Furthermore, the applicant's right to take part in communal activities was completely curtailed, which constituted a further violation of his right to respect for his private life under Article 8 of the Convention.
19.  The Court therefore finds that there has been a violation of Article 3 of the Convention in respect of the applicant's treatment in the prison.

The Court reiterates that the obligation to protect the right to life under Article 2 of the Convention also requires by implication that there be an effective official investigation when an individual has been killed or when there are reasonable grounds to fear that an individual has been killed as a result of the use of force by State agents (see, among many other authorities, İpek v. Turkey [GC], no. 48629/99, § 100, ECHR 2009-I).
81.  In the present case, the Court notes that the applicant's relatives, Beslan, Rizvan, Rizavdi and Shuddi Dolsayev, were last seen in the custody of State agents and that there are reasonable grounds to fear that they have been killed as a result of the use of force by State agents. The Court further notes that the investigation into the circumstances of their disappearance has not been effective, in particular, because of the lack of cooperation of the law-enforcement authorities in Chechnya, the failure to conduct an effective criminal investigation, the destruction of evidence and the lack of progress in the investigation.

Yekaterinburg asked the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation to extradite the applicant to Russia.  On 20 April 1994 the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation granted the extradition request.  The applicant was extradited to Russia on 11 May 1994.  In December 1994 he was sentenced to life imprisonment.

1.  The applicant complained that his extradition to Russia violated Article 7 of the Convention, which provides that no one shall be subjected to torture or inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.  He argued that he had been subjected to torture and ill-treatment in Russia, and that there was a real risk that he would be tortured or ill-treated if he were extradited to Russia.  He also argued that the extradition proceedings had been unfair and that the extradition treaty between the United Kingdom and Russia did not provide sufficient safeguards against torture or ill-treatment.
2.  The Court found that the applicant had been subjected to torture and ill-treatment in Russia, and that there was a real risk that he would be tortured or ill-treated if he were extradited to Russia.  The Court also found that the extradition proceedings had been unfair, and that the extradition treaty between the United Kingdom and Russia did not provide sufficient safeguards against torture or ill-treatment.  Accordingly, the Court held that the extradition of the applicant to Russia had violated Article 7 of the Convention.
3.  The Court awarded the applicant 10,000 euros in respect of non-pecuniary damage.

label: territories
output:
territories and the fact that the Covenant is binding on Israel as a State party’. The Committee ‘urged Israel to ensure that the provisions of the Covenant were fully implemented in the occupied territories’.
The Court considers that these statements by Israel and the Committee are relevant to its examination of the question whether the Covenant is applicable in the present case. However, the Court is not bound by the views expressed by these bodies.
111.  The Court recalls that, under customary international law, an occupying Power is obliged to respect the laws and regulations of the occupied territory, including those relating to the protection of human rights. The Hague Regulations of 1907 and the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949, which are part of customary international law, contain provisions to this effect.
112.  The Court further recalls that, under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, a State party is under an obligation to respect and to ensure the rights set forth in the Covenant ‘in all circumstances’, including in territories under its jurisdiction.
113.  The Court considers that the Covenant is applicable in the present case, since Israel exercises effective control over the occupied territories and the persons residing there. Israel has not disputed that it exercises effective control over the occupied territories. The Court finds that the applicant, Mr. El-Ad, is a person ‘residing’ in the occupied territories within the meaning of article 1 of the Covenant.
114.  The Court notes that the question whether the Covenant applies in occupied territories is not free from doubt. However, the Court considers that the general principle of effective control, as it has emerged from the practice of States and international courts, is also applicable in the context of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
115.  The Court further notes that the Covenant is a multilateral treaty and that its provisions are binding on all States parties, including Israel, in relation to the exercise of their jurisdiction over the territories under their control. The Court considers that Israel’s obligations under the Covenant extend to the occupied territories, and that the Covenant is therefore applicable in the present case.

I consider the operation to have been successful and to have been carried out without any incidents.”

He noted that the operation of the ghetto school for Romani students was contrary to the position of the Ministry of Education, which was unfavourable to schools “exclusively reserved for Gypsy students.” He also noted that the conditions in which the Romani students were studying were inadequate, and that the needs could not be met by the mayor of Aspropyrgos.

The Ombudsman recommended that the Ministry of Education take all necessary measures to ensure that the Romani students in Aspropyrgos had access to education in conditions that respected their dignity and their rights. He also recommended that the Ministry of Education review its position on schools exclusively reserved for Roma, and that it promote the integration of Roma children in mainstream schools.

label: Ozerne
output:
İstanbul in case of an emergency.
23.  The pilots took off from Adana at 19.30 hours on 26 June 1996. They were given a weather report for İstanbul, which indicated that the visibility was 1,500 meters and that there were scattered clouds at an altitude of 1,500 meters. The pilots decided to fly at an altitude of 3,000 meters in order to avoid the clouds.
24.  The aircraft disappeared from the radar screens at 20.18 hours, while it was flying at an altitude of approximately 3,000 meters. The last known position of the aircraft was approximately 20 nautical miles north-west of İstanbul.
25.  The wreckage of the aircraft was found on 27 June 1996 in the Marmara Sea, at a depth of approximately 800 meters. All 80 passengers and crew members on board were killed.
26.  The accident was caused by the failure of both engines on the aircraft. The reason for the engine failure was the ingestion of a large bird into both engines, which led to their malfunction and subsequent failure. The pilots were unable to recover from the situation and the aircraft crashed into the sea.
27.  The investigation revealed that the aircraft had been maintained in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions and that there were no technical defects that could have caused the accident.
28.  The investigation also revealed that the pilots had not received any specific training on how to deal with an engine failure caused by bird ingestion. The crew members did not follow the correct procedures for dealing with such a situation and did not make use of the available emergency equipment.
29.  The investigation recommended that airlines should provide their pilots with training on how to deal with engine failures caused by bird ingestion, and that they should also ensure that their aircraft are equipped with the necessary emergency equipment.
30.  The investigation also recommended that air traffic control authorities should take measures to prevent birds from entering the airspace around airports, and that they should provide pilots with accurate and up-to-date information on the weather conditions and the presence of birds in the area.

However, the Court considers that the restrictions on the number of visits and their duration, as well as the requirement for the meetings to take place under the supervision of a judge and security forces, may have hindered the applicant's right to consult with his lawyers effectively. The Court further notes that the applicant was not allowed to receive visits from his family members and that he was not permitted to have any contact with the outside world, including with his lawyers, between the meetings.

17.  In the UK, the right to vote is a qualified right under the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), Article 3 of Protocol No. 1, which provides:

“Everyone has the right to free elections at periodic intervals and the right to vote and to stand for election at such elections.”

The right is not absolute and may be subject to certain restrictions, but these must be in accordance with the law and proportionate to the aims pursued.

18.  In the UK, the Representation of the People Act 1983 (RPA 1983) sets out the legal framework for the right to vote. Section 3 of the RPA 1983 provides that a person is not entitled to be registered in the electoral register if they are serving a sentence of imprisonment or detention in a mental institution. The section does not specify whether the disqualification applies only to those serving a sentence of imprisonment or detention in a mental institution.

19.  In the UK, the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) has considered the issue of the right to vote for prisoners in several cases. In the case of Hirst v United Kingdom (No 2) (2005) 42 EHRR 41, the ECtHR held that the UK’s blanket ban on prisoners voting was incompatible with Article 3 of Protocol No. 1 to the ECHR. The court found that the ban was not proportionate to the aims pursued and that it did not allow for any exceptions. The UK government subsequently introduced the Representation of the People (Prisoners) Act 2009, which allows for some prisoners to vote in elections.

20.  In the UK, the issue of prisoner voting has been a subject of political and legal debate for many years. The current government’s position is that prisoners should not have the right to vote while they are in prison. This position is based on the belief that prisoners have forfeited their right to participate in democratic processes by committing crimes and breaking the law. In conclusion, the court held that the relevant legislation did not violate the Constitution or the Convention.

### Dissenting opinion

Two judges dissented from the majority opinion, arguing that the relevant legislation violated the Constitution and the Convention. They argued that the Constitution's Article 3 on the principle of equality required full equality between homosexual unions and marriages between a man and a woman. They also argued that the Convention's Article 12 on non-discrimination required full equality between homosexual unions and marriages between a man and a woman.

### Impact

The decision in Goodwin v United Kingdom had a significant impact on the legal recognition of same-sex relationships in the UK. It effectively ruled out the possibility of same-sex couples having the same legal rights as opposite-sex couples in the UK, and it was not until 2004 that the UK government introduced civil partnerships for same-sex couples, which provided many of the same legal rights as marriage. It was not until 2013 that same-sex marriage was legalized in the UK, with the passage of the Marriage (Same Sex Couples) Act 2013.

The  CPT  has  repeatedly  drawn  attention  to  the  need  for  a  clear  division  of  responsibilities  between  the  prison  administration  and  the  health  authorities,  with  the  latter  being  responsible  for  the  provision  of  health  care  services  to  prisoners.  This  is  in  line  with  the  principle  of  the  best  interest  of  the  child,  which  requires  that  the  child's  health  and  development  be  given  primary  consideration.  The  Committee  on  the  Rights  of  the  Child  has  emphasised  the  importance  of  ensuring  that  children  in  detention  have  access  to  appropriate  health  care  services,  including  preventive  and  curative  care,  and  that  their  health  needs  are  met  in  a  timely  manner.
In  Bulgaria,  the  CPT  recommended  that  the  Ministry  of  Justice  and  the  Ministry  of  Health  should  establish  a  clear  division  of  responsibilities  with  regard  to  the  provision  of  health  care  services  to  prisoners.  The  CPT  also  recommended  that  the  prison  administration  should  ensure  that  prisoners  have  access  to  appropriate  health  care  services,  including  preventive  and  curative  care,  and  that  their  health  needs  are  met  in  a  timely  manner.  The  CPT  further  recommended  that  the  prison  administration  should  ensure  that  prisoners  have  access  to  specialist  health  care  services  as  needed,  and  that  health  care  staff  should  receive  appropriate  training  and  support.
In  its  concluding  observations  on  Bulgaria's  initial  report  under  the  Convention  on  the  Rights  of  the  Child,  the  Committee  on  the  Rights  of  the  Child  expressed  concern

58.  The plaintiff appealed the judgment to the Istanbul Regional Appellate Court, which, in a judgment of 26 October 2001, upheld the lower court’s decision. The appellate court held that the plaintiff’s claim was unfounded and that the seizure and detention of the vessel had been in compliance with domestic law and the Montreux Convention.
59.  The plaintiff then appealed to the Supreme Court of Appeals, which, in a judgment of 27 May 2003, dismissed the appeal and upheld the judgment of the lower courts. The Supreme Court of Appeals held that the seizure and detention of the vessel had been in compliance with domestic law and the Montreux Convention.
60.  The plaintiff then brought the present case before the European Court of Human Rights, alleging that the seizure and detention of the vessel had violated Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention.
61.  The Court notes that the present case concerns the seizure and detention of a vessel by the Turkish authorities in 1998. The Court recalls that Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention provides that everyone has the right to the peaceful enjoyment of his possessions. It further recalls that the interference with the right to the peaceful enjoyment of possessions must be in accordance with the law and proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued.
62.  The Court notes that the Turkish courts have found that the seizure and detention of the vessel were in compliance with domestic law and the Montreux Convention governing the İstanbul Strait. The Court further notes that the plaintiff has not provided any evidence to show that the seizure and detention of the vessel were not in compliance with the law or that they were disproportionate to the legitimate aim pursued.
63.  In view of the above, the Court finds that there has been no violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention in the present case.
64.  Accordingly, the Court dismisses the application as manifestly ill-founded, pursuant to

label: Autonomous region of Krajina
output:
Krajina”. The applicant was forced to leave his home in Sisak in 1993 because of the war and went to live in Zagreb. In 1995 the Croatian armed forces launched an operation to retake the territory of Krajina, which resulted in the displacement of a large number of Serbs. The applicant was not able to return to his home in Sisak after the end of the war.

7.   The applicant submitted his application to the Croatian authorities for the restitution of his property in Sisak in 2001. In 2002 the authorities declared his property to be state property and in 2003 they sold it to a third party. The applicant challenged the decision before the domestic courts, arguing that the authorities had not complied with the restitution procedure and that he had not been given an opportunity to be heard. The domestic courts rejected his claims and the Constitutional Court of Croatia refused to review the case.

8.   Relying on Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention, the applicant complained that the Croatian authorities had deprived him of his property without compensation and that there had been no effective restitution procedure. He also relied on Article 6 § 1 of the Convention, arguing that he had not had an effective opportunity to be heard in the restitution proceedings.

9.   The Court found a violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention, as the authorities had not provided the applicant with an effective restitution procedure and had not compensated him for the loss of his property. The Court also found a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention, as the applicant had not had an effective opportunity to be heard in the restitution proceedings.

10.   The Court awarded the applicant 20,000 euros in respect of non-pecuniary damage and 2,000 euros in respect of costs and expenses.

The court ordered Russia to pay €200,000 (US$270,000) in damages to each of the 23 applicants.

### Polish investigation

In 2011, the Institute of National Remembrance (IPN) in Poland announced that it had found new evidence linking Soviet officials to the massacre. The IPN said that it had discovered documents showing that the NKVD had transported the prisoners to the Katyn forest in 1940, and that the killings had been carried out by a special NKVD unit. The IPN also said that it had found witnesses who had seen the prisoners being transported to the forest and heard their cries for help.

In 2012, the Polish government announced that it had found new evidence linking Soviet officials to the massacre. The government said that it had discovered a document signed by Lavrentiy Beria, the head of the NKVD, which ordered the execution of the prisoners. The document was found in the Soviet archives and was dated 5 March 1940.

In 2016, the Polish Institute of National Remembrance announced that it had found a previously unknown mass grave containing the remains of Polish officers who were killed by the NKVD in the Katyn forest. The institute said that the grave contained the remains of at least 10 people, and that it was likely that there were more graves in the area that had yet to be discovered.

11.  Ilinden brought an action before the Bulgarian courts challenging the refusal to register it as a political party.  In its action, Ilinden argued, inter alia, that the prohibition on the use of the term “Macedonian” in the name of a political party was contrary to Article 11 of the European Convention on Human Rights (“the Convention”), which guarantees the right to freedom of assembly and association.

12.  The Bulgarian courts rejected Ilinden's action, holding, inter alia, that the prohibition on the use of the term “Macedonian” in the name of a political party was necessary in order to protect the country's national unity and prevent ethnic tensions.

13.  Ilinden then brought the present application to the European Court of Human Rights, alleging that Bulgaria had violated its right to freedom of assembly and association, as guaranteed by Article 11 of the Convention, by refusing to register it as a political party on account of the use of the term “Macedonian” in its name.

14.  The European Court of Human Rights found that there had been a violation of Article 11 of the Convention, as the prohibition on the use of the term “Macedonian” in the name of a political party was not necessary in a democratic society and was disproportionate to the aim of protecting national unity and preventing ethnic tensions.

15.  The Court noted that the term “Macedonian” was not an ethnic term, but rather a geographical and historical one, and that the use of the term in the name of a political party did not necessarily imply a

The Court further noted that the applicant had been unable to obtain any effective investigation into the circumstances surrounding his brother’s death.

label: Dniester
output:
Dniester river, and on 16 June the ROG’s troops entered Tighina, which was thereafter under Russian control. The ROG’s actions were supported by the Russian government, which on 27 June declared that it would not recognize any territorial changes in the region. The situation was aggravated by the fact that the ROG’s troops were not under the control of the Moldovan authorities and that the Russian government refused to cooperate with the Moldovan authorities in the framework of the Joint Control Commission, established by the 1990 Treaty of Friendship and Cooperation between Moldova and Russia.

The conflict resulted in the displacement of a significant number of people, mostly Moldovans, who fled the fighting and the humanitarian situation in the region was dire. The international community, particularly the OSCE, the Council of Europe and the European Union, tried to mediate the conflict and to find a peaceful solution, but their efforts were hampered by the lack of cooperation from the Russian government.

The conflict ended in 1992 with the signing of the “Agreement on the principles for the settlement of the Transdniestrian problem” between Moldova and Russia, which provided for a ceasefire, the establishment of a Joint Control Commission and the holding of a referendum in Transdniestria on its status. The agreement was never implemented, however, due to the refusal of the separatist leadership to participate in the referendum and the continuing presence of the ROG in the region. The conflict remains unresolved to this day, with the Transdniestrian region de facto independent and under the control of separatist authorities.

In conclusion, the conflict in Transdniestria was a result of a combination of factors, including the legacy of the Soviet Union, the ethnic and linguistic divisions in the region, the lack of political will of the Moldovan authorities to find a peaceful solution, and the support of the Russian government for the separatists. The conflict had a significant impact on the region and its people, and it remains unresolved to this day.

The Court found that the Russian authorities had not conducted an effective investigation into the circumstances of the killing of the Bersunkayev family, despite the fact that the applicant had provided a detailed account of the events and had submitted evidence supporting her allegations. The Court also noted that the applicant’s account of the events was consistent with the other available evidence, including the testimony of the neighbour and the fact that the men who raided the house spoke Russian without an accent.

The Court further found that the killing of the Bersunkayev family constituted an extrajudicial execution, which is a violation of the right to life protected by Article 2 of the Convention. The Court noted that the fact that the men who carried out the execution were members of the federal forces, as well as the absence of any effective investigation into the incident, supported the conclusion that the killing was carried out by state agents.

The Court also found that the killing of the Bersunkayev family was committed with the knowledge or consent of the Russian authorities, as there was evidence that the federal forces were involved in the incident and that the authorities had failed to conduct an effective investigation into the circumstances of the killing. The Court therefore held that there had been a violation of Article 2 of the Convention in respect of the killing of the Bersunkayev family.

The Court also found a violation of Article 5 of the Convention, as the applicant’s brother-in-law had been detained by unknown persons and had subsequently disappeared, and the Russian authorities had failed to conduct an effective investigation into his disappearance. The Court noted that the applicant had submitted evidence indicating that her brother-in-law had been taken away by the federal forces, and that the authorities had failed to provide any information about his whereabouts or fate.

The Court further found that there had been a violation of Article 13 of the Convention, as the applicant had had no effective remedy in respect of the violations of Article 2 and Article 5 of the Convention. The Court noted that the applicant had been unable to obtain a thorough and effective investigation into the circumstances of the killing of her family members and the disappearance of her brother-in-law, and that the domestic remedies available to her had been ineffective in this respect.

1996 judgment. The applicants denied the claim and argued that they had acquired the land by adverse possession. The case was pending before the court at the time of the introduction of the 2001 Land Act.

In 2002, the applicants filed a counterclaim seeking the recognition of their title to the disputed land under the 2001 Land Act. They argued that the land had been in their possession for over ten years and that they had developed it, invested in it and paid taxes on it. They also argued that the State had failed to prove that the land was State forest land. The counterclaim was dismissed by the court in 2004.

In 2006, the High Court upheld the dismissal of the counterclaim and held that the applicants had not acquired title to the land by adverse possession. The court found that the land was State forest land and that the applicants had not fulfilled the conditions for adverse possession. The court also held that the 2001 Land Act did not apply to the case because it was enacted after the applicants had taken possession of the land.

The applicants appealed to the Supreme Court, which dismissed the appeal in 2008. The Supreme Court held that the High Court had correctly applied the law and that the applicants had not acquired title to the land by adverse possession. The court also held that the 2001 Land Act did not apply to the case because it was enacted after the applicants had taken possession of the land.

The applicants complained that their right to property had been violated, relying on Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention, which provides:

"Every natural or legal person is entitled to the peaceful enjoyment of his possessions. No one shall be deprived of his possessions except in the public interest and subject to the conditions provided for by law and by the general principles of international law.

The preceding provisions shall not, however, in any way impair the right of a State or of any other public authority to take such measures as are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of its security or public safety, or to protect public health or morals, or to control the use of property in accordance with the general interest

22 building, disturbed the applicants’ peaceful enjoyment of their property.

The applicants complained to the police on several occasions, but the situation did not improve. The police, when they did intervene, would only disperse the crowd for a short time, and the club’s clients would soon return. The applicants alleged that the police were bribed by the club’s owners.

The applicants brought an action before the local court, seeking an injunction to stop the noise and disturbance caused by the club’s clients. The court dismissed the action, holding that the noise and disturbance were not sufficiently serious to warrant an injunction. The applicants appealed, but the appellate court upheld the decision of the lower court.

The applicants then lodged a complaint with the European Court of Human Rights, alleging that their right to peaceful enjoyment of their property under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention had been violated.

Held:
The application was admissible.

The Court found that there had been a violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention. It noted that the noise and disturbance caused by the club’s clients had significantly impaired the applicants’ enjoyment of their property and that the authorities had not taken adequate measures to prevent the disturbance. The Court also noted that the applicants had exhausted all available domestic remedies and that the respondent State had not offered any justification for the violation of the applicants’ rights.

The Court awarded the applicants 15,000 euros in respect of non-pecuniary damage.

The Court also found that the applicant's conviction had been based on evidence obtained through torture. The Court further found that the applicant had been denied access to a lawyer during the initial stages of his detention and that his trial had been unfair.

The Court held that Russia had violated the applicant's rights under Article 3 (prohibition of inhuman or degrading treatment) and Article 6 (right to a fair trial) of the European Convention on Human Rights. The Court awarded the applicant 50,000 euros in respect of non-pecuniary damage.

label: Eastern Mediterranean
output:
1990s. The country’s geographical position, its political stability, its modern infrastructure and its attractive climate have all contributed to its popularity as a destination for tourists, including those who engage in sex tourism. The presence of numerous foreign women, particularly from Eastern Europe, who work in the tourist industry, has also created a demand for sexual services, which has been met by trafficking in women.
30. The problem of trafficking in women is not new to Cyprus. It has been reported since the early 1990s, but it is only in recent years that it has become a matter of public concern. The police have been carrying out operations to combat the problem, but the number of women being trafficked into the country has continued to increase.
31. The majority of women who are trafficked into Cyprus come from Eastern Europe, particularly from Bulgaria, Romania, Ukraine and Moldova. They are recruited through deception, often by promises of well-paid jobs, and are brought to Cyprus by traffickers who have established networks in their home countries. On arrival, they are often forced into prostitution and are kept in conditions of virtual slavery. They are subjected to physical and sexual violence, and are not allowed to leave their place of work or to communicate with the outside world.
32. The trafficking of women for sexual exploitation is a serious violation of human rights. It involves the use of force, fraud or coercion to exploit women for commercial sexual purposes. It is a form of modern-day slavery and is a serious crime under both Cypriot and international law. It is also a major challenge to the rule of law and to the protection of human rights in Cyprus.”
92. The Council of Europe Commissioner for Human Rights also noted in his report that:
“33. The Cypriot authorities have taken a number of steps to combat trafficking in women, including the establishment of a special police unit to investigate cases of trafficking and the adoption of a national action plan to combat trafficking. The authorities have also signed the relevant international conventions and have ratified the Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, Especially Women and Children.

The Supreme Administrative Ethics Chamber of Lithuania dismissed the applicant’s cassation appeal, finding that the appellate court had correctly applied the law and that the decision was supported by the evidence.
The applicant complained under Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention that the authorities had deprived him of his property without compensation.
The Court reiterated that Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 guarantees the right of property, which includes the right to possess, use, sell or otherwise dispose of property. The Court also reiterated that the Contracting States have a wide margin of appreciation in determining the conditions and procedures for the acquisition and disposal of property. However, this margin is not unlimited and the Court must scrutinise the case-law of the Contracting State to ensure that the measures taken are in conformity with the requirements of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1.
The Court noted that the applicant had been deprived of his property by the Vilnius local authority’s decision of 14 February 2000, which had been upheld by the courts. The Court further noted that the applicant had not been compensated for the loss of his property.
The Court found that the applicant had been deprived of his property without compensation in breach of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention. It held that the authorities had failed to strike a fair balance between the public interest and the applicant’s right to property, and that the applicant had not been offered adequate compensation for the loss of his property.
The Court therefore held that there had been a violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 to the Convention.
The Court awarded the applicant 10,000 euros (EUR) in respect of non-pecuniary damage, plus any tax that may be chargeable.

The applicant’s parents lodged a complaint with the European Court of Human Rights on 24 April 2001. They alleged, inter alia, that the authorities had violated Article 5 of the Convention (right to liberty and security) and Article 13 (right to an effective remedy) in respect of their son.

In its decision of 10 November 2005, the European Court of Human Rights found a violation of Article 5 of the Convention in respect of the applicant’s detention and of Article 13 in respect of the lack of an effective remedy. The Court held, in particular, that:

* The applicant had been detained on 3 November 2000 and had been held in custody until 20 November 2000, without any court order or any other legal basis. The detention had therefore been in contravention of Article 5 § 1 (right to liberty and security) of the Convention.
* The applicant had had no effective remedy in respect of his detention, as the domestic courts had not examined the lawfulness of his detention. This had also violated Article 13 of the Convention.

The Court awarded the applicant 30,000 euros in respect of non-pecuniary damage.

### The applicant's complaint under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention

6.  The applicant complained that she had been denied a fair trial in the proceedings concerning the validity of the special-purpose settlement order.  She argued that the domestic courts had failed to provide her with an effective remedy for the violation of her rights.

### The Government's submissions

7.  The Government submitted that the applicant's complaint under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention was unfounded.  They argued that the applicant had had an effective remedy in the form of judicial proceedings before the domestic courts.  The Government further submitted that the domestic courts had examined the case thoroughly and had given the applicant a fair hearing.

### The Court's assessment

8.  The Court notes that the applicant complained under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention about the lack of a fair trial in the proceedings concerning the validity of the special-purpose settlement order.  In this connection, the Court reiterates that the right to a fair trial, as guaranteed by Article 6 § 1 of the Convention, encompasses the right to a public hearing within a reasonable time, the right to be informed of the charges, the right to examine or have examined the witnesses against one, the right to have the assistance of a lawyer, the right to an impartial tribunal and the right to a fair and public hearing of the defence.  The Court further reiterates that these rights are not absolute and may be subject to limitations, but such limitations must be in accordance with the law and necessary in a democratic society.

9.  The Court notes that the applicant was not represented by a lawyer in the domestic proceedings.  The Court further notes that the domestic courts did not examine the case thoroughly and did not provide the applicant with a fair hearing.  In particular, the Court notes that the Neryungri Town Court did not examine the merits of the applicant's claim and did not give her an opportunity to present her case. 1.  On 18 June 1992, the Bosnian Serb Assembly declared the creation of the “Republika Srpska” (“RS”), which purported to be an independent state within Bosnia and Herzegovina. The RS was established on territories controlled by Bosnian Serb forces, and its creation was not recognized by the Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina or any other state. The RS was governed by a President, a National Assembly, and a Government, all of which were controlled by Bosnian Serb political and military leaders. The RS was also provided with its own armed forces, known as the “Army of the Republika Srpska” (“VRS”), which was formed from units of the JNA and the Bosnian Serb Territorial Defence.
2.  The conflict between the Bosnian Serb forces and the Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina, supported by the Croatian Army, continued throughout 1992 and resulted in significant atrocities, including the Srebrenica genocide in July 1995. The conflict also resulted in the displacement of hundreds of thousands of people and widespread destruction of homes, businesses, and infrastructure.
3.  On 14 December 1995, the General Framework Agreement for Peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina (the “Dayton Agreement”) was signed in Paris, France, by the Presidents of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, and Serbia. The Dayton Agreement established a framework for a peaceful resolution of the conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including the establishment of a Bosnian government and the creation of two entities: the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Republika Srpska. 33.  On 21 July 1998 the European Group on Ethics in Science and New Technologies (EGE) to the European Commission issued Opinion no. 11 “On Ethical aspects of human tissue banking”. Its relevant parts read:
“2.3 Information and consent
The procurement of human tissues requires, as a principle, the prior, informed and free consent of the person concerned. This does not apply in the case of tissue procurement ordered by a judge in the context of judicial, in particular criminal, proceedings.
While consent is a fundamental ethical principle in human tissue banking, it may be limited or waived in certain circumstances. For example, in cases where the tissue is to be used for research, the need to protect the donor’s identity may override the requirement for consent. However, such limitations must be justified in the light of ethical principles and must be subject to appropriate safeguards.
2.4 Research on human tissues
Research on human tissues raises a number of ethical issues. The use of human tissues for research purposes must be subject to strict ethical controls. Researchers must ensure that the tissues are obtained and used in accordance with ethical principles and that the dignity and rights of the donor are respected.
In particular, researchers must ensure that the tissues are obtained from individuals who have given informed consent for their use in research. The consent process must be transparent and comprehensive, and the donor must be provided with all relevant information about the research project.
Researchers must also ensure that the tissues are used in a manner that is consistent with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki. In particular, they must ensure that the tissues are not used in ways that would be harmful to the donor or that would violate their dignity.
2.5 Commercial use of human tissues
The commercial use of human tissues raises a number of ethical issues. The tissues must be obtained and used in accordance with ethical principles, and the dignity and rights of the donor must be respected.
In particular, the commercial use of human tissues must be subject to strict ethical controls. The tissues must be obtained from individuals who have given informed consent for their use in commercial activities. The consent process must be transparent

It is not suggested that these conditions are not stringent enough to ensure that [the fifth applicant] does not pose a real and present danger to the security of the realm. But the conditions are not such as to render it impossible for him to engage in activities which might further his terrorist purposes. In these circumstances, the fact that he is a UK national is of little assistance to the appellants’ argument.
36.  The final step in the appellants’ argument is that, even if the Secretary of State has power to detain suspected international terrorists indefinitely, that power is subject to constitutional limitations. The appellants rely on the European Convention on Human Rights and the Human Rights Act 1998. They submit that the power to detain without charge or trial is incompatible with the right to liberty and security of the person under Article 5 of the Convention. They also submit that the power to detain indefinitely is incompatible with the right to a fair trial under Article 6 of the Convention. They rely on the decision of the European Court of Human Rights in the case of A v United Kingdom (2002) 35 EHRR 243, in which the Court held that the United Kingdom’s system of control orders, under which suspected international terrorists were subject to a range of restrictive measures, was incompatible with Article 5 and Article 6 of the Convention. They submit that the same is true of the power to detain suspected international terrorists indefinitely.
37.  In our view, the appellants’ argument on this point is not well founded. The power to detain suspected international terrorists indefinitely is not incompatible with Article 5 or Article 6 of the Convention. The power is subject to the supervision of the courts, and it is subject to the procedural safeguards which have been developed by the courts in the context of the common law. The power is not unlimited. It is subject to the requirement that the Secretary of State must have reasonable grounds for believing that the detention is necessary to protect national security. It is subject to the requirement that the detention must be proportionate to the risk which the suspected international terrorist poses to national

The second dissenting opinion argued that the National Radio and Television Council had erred in law when it had found that the broadcasting of the image of 17 April had not constituted a breach of the prohibition of incitement to hatred. According to the dissenting judge, the broadcasting of the image had been capable of inciting hatred, and the National Radio and Television Council had not taken into account the context in which the broadcasting had taken place, including the fact that the image had been broadcast on the eve of the national elections.

In its decision, the Constitutional Court noted that the freedom of the press was a fundamental right, but it was not an unlimited right. In particular, the right to impart information was subject to restrictions, such as the prohibition of incitement to hatred. The Court also noted that the National Radio and Television Council had found that the broadcasting of the image of 17 April had not constituted a breach of the prohibition of incitement to hatred, and that this finding was based on an overall assessment of the context in which the broadcasting had taken place.

The Constitutional Court further noted that the right to impart information was particularly important in the context of television broadcasting, given the special nature of this medium. However, this did not mean that the National Radio and Television Council’s decision was necessarily correct. In particular, the Court noted that the National Radio and Television Council had not taken into account the fact that the image of 17 April had been recorded by secret means, and that this fact alone could have justified the prohibition of its broadcasting.

In light of the above, the Constitutional Court concluded that there were no grounds for annulling the National Radio and Television Council’s decision. However, the Court also noted that the National Radio and Television Council should be more cautious in the future when assessing the compatibility of the broadcasting of potentially sensitive material with the prohibition of incitement to hatred. In particular, the Council should take into account the context in which the broadcasting takes place, including the potential impact of the broadcasting on public order and the political climate in the country.

The decision of the Constitutional Court was welcomed by some as a balanced and well-reasoned approach to the issue of the broadcasting of potentially sensitive material. Others

2 offices, to search for and seize any illegal software, and to arrest the persons found in the offices. The operation was carried out by a team of 10 officers from the Varna Regional Directorate of the National Police Service. The team included 3 police officers, 4 operational officers from the Ministry of Interior and 3 customs officers. The team was divided into 2 groups. The first group entered the first office and the second group entered the second office. The team was accompanied by Ya.K. and 2 other officers from the CSCOC. The operation was filmed by a camera installed by the CSCOC. The operation was carried out without any prior notification to the company or to the persons who were later arrested.

1. The operation began at around 10.00 a.m. on 18 June 2008. The officers entered the two offices and started to search for illegal software. They found a large number of computer equipment, including computers, laptops, servers, hard disks, CDs and DVDs. They also found a large number of documents and other materials. The officers seized all the computer equipment and documents found in the offices. They also arrested 6 persons who were present in the offices at the time of the operation. The arrested persons were taken to the Varna Regional Directorate of the National Police Service for questioning.
2. The operation was carried out in a very rough and violent manner. The officers involved in the operation used excessive force when entering the offices and when arresting the persons found there. They also used physical violence against some of the persons arrested. The operation caused significant damage to the company’s property, including to the computer equipment and the documents seized.
3. The operation was filmed by the camera installed by the CSCOC. The footage shows that the officers involved in the operation acted in a very rough and violent manner. It also shows that the arrested persons were treated in a humiliating and degrading manner.
4. The operation was immediately reported to the public prosecutor’s office in Varna. The prosecutor ordered an investigation into the circumstances of the operation and the allegations of excessive use of force and ill-treatment of the arrested persons.
5. The investigation was carried out by the Varna Regional Directorate of the National Police Service and the Varna Regional Prosecutor’s Office.

The MNF was responsible for the security of the region and for maintaining law and order. The British forces were responsible for providing security in the MNF’s Area of Operations, which included Basra City. The British forces had their own chain of command, but they were integrated with the US forces and were subject to US command and control.
120.  In these circumstances, it is difficult to conclude that the United Kingdom had effective control of Basra City. The US military had overall command of the region and the MNF was responsible for security and law and order. The British forces were part of the MNF and were responsible for providing security in the MNF’s Area of Operations, but they were integrated with the US forces and were subject to US command and control. It is true that the British forces had a significant role in providing security in Basra City, but that does not necessarily mean that the United Kingdom had effective control of the city.
121.  In my view, it would be difficult to conclude that the United Kingdom had effective control of Basra City during the period in question, such as to fix the United Kingdom with jurisdiction under the “effective control of an area” doctrine. The fact that British forces were present in Basra City and were responsible for providing security in the MNF’s Area of Operations does not, in my view, amount to effective control of the city. The US military had overall command of the region and the MNF was responsible for security and law and order. The British forces were part of the MNF and were subject to US command and control. In those circumstances, it is difficult to conclude that the United Kingdom had effective control of Basra City.”

The establishment of the NKAO was the result of an agreement between the Soviet government and the leaders of the local Armenian population, who sought autonomy in order to protect their cultural and political rights. The NKAO was granted a high degree of autonomy, including its own legislative, executive, and judicial bodies, as well as its own flag and anthem.
2.  The population of the NKAO was predominantly Armenian, with Armenians constituting some 75% of the population. The Azerbaijani population, which was concentrated in the regional capital, Stepanakert, was estimated to be around 20%. The remaining 5% of the population was composed of Russians, Kurds, and other ethnic groups.
3.  The Nagorno-Karabakh conflict began in the late 1980s, as the Soviet Union was in the process of disintegration. The conflict was sparked by demands from the local Armenian population for unification with the Armenian SSR. This led to clashes between Armenian and Azerbaijani forces, with the Armenians eventually gaining control over the NKAO and neighbouring territories.
4.  The conflict has since escalated into a full-scale war between Armenia and Azerbaijan, with the latter receiving military support from Turkey. The war has resulted in significant loss of life and displacement of populations, with thousands of people killed and hundreds of thousands displaced.

6.  The conflict has significant geopolitical implications, as it has strained relations between Russia and Turkey, and has also impacted regional energy security.

On 24 July 1995, the government announced that it had set up a commission of inquiry to investigate the events of 12-13 May 1995. The commission was composed of five members, including two members of parliament, a representative of the Ministry of the Interior, a representative of the Ministry of Health and a representative of the Ministry of Justice. The commission was given a mandate to investigate the circumstances surrounding the events, to identify those responsible and to make recommendations for preventing similar events in the future.

On 27 July 1995, the Eyüp Assize Court ordered the release of the police officers from custody, stating that there was no evidence to support the allegations of torture and ill-treatment. The court also decided to merge the cases involving the deaths of Dilek Şimşek Sevinç, Reis Kopal, Zeynep Poyraz, Fevzi Tunç, Fadime Bingöl, Ali Yıldırım and Mehmet Gündüz into a single case.
